title: Hardy v. Gunter
description: In this termination of parental rights case, the Court of Appeals analyzes the efficacy of S.C. Code Ann. section 20-7-1572(3) (failure to visit) and section 20-7-1572(4) (failure to support) as grounds for termination of the father's parental rights.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Diane Cannon Hardy and James Hardy, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Shane Courtland Cannon Gunter, Tyler Cannon Gunter, minors and John 
        S. Gunter, Jr., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â Tommy B. Edwards, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3595
Heard January 14, 2003 - Filed February 
  3, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Raymond William Godwin, of Greenville; for Appellants.
Robert K. Whitney, of Seneca; for Respondents.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  In this termination of parental 
  rights case, Diane Cannon Hardy and James Hardy (mother and stepfather) appeal 
  from an order of the family court denying their plea to terminate the parental 
  rights of John S. Gunter, Jr. (the father) to his two minor children.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The mother and father were married 
  in April 1988.Â  They have two children, Shane and Tyler, born on November 18, 
  1992 and March 1, 1995, respectively.Â  During the marriage, the father retired 
  as a major from the United States Air Force, having earned two masterâ€™s degrees 
  during his military service.
The mother and father separated 
  in June 1996.Â  During the same month, the father admitted himself to the Anderson 
  Area Medical Center Psychiatric Ward where he was diagnosed with depression 
  and drug addiction.
The parties were divorced by order of the family 
  court dated November 8, 1996.Â  Pursuant to the divorce decree, which embodied 
  the partiesâ€™ settlement agreement, the mother was granted full custody of the 
  children.Â  Visitation for the father was held in abeyance pending the fatherâ€™s 
  compliance with requirements that he obtain a psychological evaluation from 
  the Veteranâ€™s Administration (VA) and approval to visit the children from the 
  guardian ad litem.Â  The order specifically provided that â€œupon receipt of the 
  recommendation of the Guardian Ad Litem . . . the Court, without further hearing, 
  may review the same and adopt the recommendation . . . as the order of this 
  Court, however, either party may request a hearing on the visitation as recommended 
  within 30 days of the receipt of such recommendation.â€Â  Determination of the 
  fatherâ€™s child support obligation was held in abeyance.
In December 1996, the father began receiving disability 
  payments totaling $1,345 per month. [1] Â  Simultaneously, the partiesâ€™ children each began receiving 
  $212 monthly social security checks related to the fatherâ€™s disability status. 
  Â The father has made no additional support payments for the children.
After the partiesâ€™ divorce, the 
  father moved to Florida in order to be near and assist his mother, who has been 
  diagnosed with Alzheimerâ€™s disease, and his father, who has been diagnosed with 
  congestive heart failure. Â In addition, the fatherâ€™s son from a former 
  marriage resides in Florida.
Although the divorce degree specifically 
  directed that the fatherâ€™s psychological evaluation be conducted through the 
  VA and the father obtained two evaluations from the VA prior to the entry of 
  the divorce decree, the guardian ad litem desired a doctor independent from 
  the VA to do an evaluation.Â  The father consented to have the evaluation performed 
  by the doctor of the guardianâ€™s choosing.Â  The guardian arranged for Dr. Spurgeon 
  Cole to evaluate the father in her office on October 13, 1998.Â  The father arrived 
  at the guardianâ€™s office at the appointed time, but Dr. Cole did not appear.Â  
  The father agreed to reschedule with Dr. Cole; however, at a December 8, 1998 
  interview with the guardian, he declared his reluctance to be evaluated by a 
  psychologist whose base of operation was in Oconee County and expressed financial 
  concerns about having the evaluation carried out by a doctor not associated 
  with the VA. Â In August 1999, the father provided the guardian with the 
  notes from a third evaluation administered by Dr. Phillip Tate of the VA in 
  Florida.Â  The father testified that he â€œwas calling [the guardian] at least 
  once every couple weeks . . . to see what [he] could do to hasten the process.â€Â  
  The father went on to state:Â  â€œI know Iâ€™ve made lots of phone calls to try to 
  make appointments, to have her call me.Â  Iâ€™ve left you know, many, many messages 
  and we . . . went through my phone log . . . and I think that she finally said 
  that, â€˜Yes, you know, you have been trying to get in touch with me.â€™â€Â  The guardian 
  admittedly received both the notes from the fatherâ€™s third evaluation and several 
  follow-up telephone calls from the father; however, the guardian never made 
  any proposal to the parties or the family court regarding the fatherâ€™s visitation 
  with the children.Â  The father has not visited with the children since the date 
  of the divorce order holding the issue of visitation in abeyance. 
The mother and stepfather were married 
  in September 1997.Â  On December 9, 1999, they instituted the instant action 
  against the father, alleging the fatherâ€™s parental rights be terminated due 
  to willful failure to visit and/or support the children and seeking an order 
  of adoption establishing a parent/child relationship between the stepfather 
  and the minor children.Â  The mother and stepfatherâ€™s complaint also alleged 
  the fatherâ€™s parental rights should be terminated based on a diagnosable condition 
  (drug addiction and mental illness), which condition was not likely to change 
  within a reasonable time and rendered him unfit to provide minimally acceptable 
  care for the children; however, the mother and stepfather abandoned this ground 
  for termination at trial.Â  Proceeding pro se, the father answered the 
  complaint, denying the mother and stepfather were entitled to the requested 
  relief.
By order dated October 16, 2000, 
  the family court found the fatherâ€™s conduct following his separation and divorce 
  from the mother did not constitute willful failure to visit and support the 
  children.Â  Accordingly, the court denied the mother and stepfatherâ€™s petition 
  for termination of the fatherâ€™s parental rights and ordered the guardian ad 
  litem to enter a recommendation as to visitation between the father and children 
  within fifteen days of the order. Â The mother and stepfatherâ€™s post-trial 
  motion for reconsideration was denied without a hearing.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a termination of parental rights case, the best 
  interests of the children are the paramount consideration.Â  South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 
  (Ct. App. 2001); South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Smith, 343 S.C. 
  129, 133, 538 S.E.2d 285, 287 (Ct. App. 2000); South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. 
  Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
  Grounds for termination of parental rights must be proved by clear and convincing 
  evidence.Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 366 
  (1999); South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 52, 
  413 S.E.2d 835, 838 (1992) (citing Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 
  747-48, 102 S.Ct. 1388, 1391-92, 71 L.Ed.2d 599, 603 (1982) (The United States 
  Supreme Court held: â€œBefore a State may sever completely and irrevocably the 
  rights of parents in their natural child, due process requires that the State 
  support its allegations by at least clear and convincing evidence.â€)); Cummings, 
  345 S.C. at 293, 547 S.E.2d at 509; Parker, 336 S.C. at 254, 519 S.E.2d 
  at 354.
On appeal of a termination of parental rights case, 
  the court of appeals may review the entire record to make a determination of 
  the facts according to our view of the evidence.Â  Richland County Depâ€™t of 
  Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 866 (1998); Cummings, 
  345 S.C. at 293, 547 S.E.2d at 509.Â  â€œThis Court may review the record and make 
  its own findings whether clear and convincing evidence supports termination.â€Â  
  Cummings, 345 S.C. at 293, 547 S.E.2d at 509; accord Parker, 
  336 S.C. at 254, 519 S.E.2d at 354; South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. 
  Humphreys, 297 S.C. 118, 121, 374 S.E.2d 922, 924 (Ct. App. 1988).Â Â  â€œOur 
  broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings below or 
  ignore the fact the trial judge was in a better position to assess the credibility 
  of the witnesses.â€Â  Cummings, 345 S.C. at 293, 547 S.E.2d at 509; accord 
  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 
  477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996); Berry v. Ianuario, 286 S.C. 522, 
  525, 335 S.E.2d 250, 251 (Ct. App. 1985).
  Our supreme court has held that a finding 
  of a willful failure to visit will not be predicated upon parental conduct that 
  can be reasonably explained.Â  Wilson v. Higgins, 294 S.C. 300, 305, 363 
  S.E.2d 911, 914 (Ct. App. 1987), revâ€™d in part on other grounds, Joiner 
  ex rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 536 S.E.2d 372 (2000).Â  A finding 
  of willful failure to support will not be predicated upon parental conduct that 
  can be reasonably explained.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Failure to Support
The mother and stepfather claim the family court 
  erred in not finding the father willfully failed to support the children from 
  the time the parties separated in June 1996 until December 1996, and the failure, 
  if proven, should serve as a basis for termination of the fatherâ€™s parental 
  rights.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
South Carolina Code Annotated section 
  20-7-1572(4) (Supp. 2001) provides for termination of parental rights upon a 
  finding that termination is in the best interest of the child and:

The child has lived outside the home of either parent for 
  a period of six months, and during that time the parent has wilfully failed 
  to support the child.Â  Failure to support means that the parent has failed to 
  make a material contribution to the childâ€™s care.Â  A material contribution consists 
  of either financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions 
  of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according 
  to the parentâ€™s means.Â  The court may consider all relevant circumstances in 
  determining whether or not the parent has wilfully failed to support the child, 
  including requests for support by the custodian and the ability of the parent 
  to provide support.

Whether a parentâ€™s failure to support 
  a child is â€œwillfulâ€ within the meaning of section 20-7-1572 is a question of 
  intent to be determined by the facts and circumstances of each case.Â  Broome, 
  307 S.C. at 52, 413 S.E.2d at 838; South Carolina Depâ€™t of Social Servs. 
  v. Wilson, 344 S.C. 332, 336, 543 S.E.2d 580, 582 (Ct. App. 2001); Parker, 
  336 S.C. at 256, 519 S.E.2d at 355.Â  Generally, the family court is given wide 
  discretion in making this conclusion.Â  However, the element of willfulness must 
  be established by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Broome, 307 S.C. at 
  52, 413 S.E.2d at 838; Wilson, 344 S.C. at 336, 543 S.E.2d at 582; Parker, 
  336 S.C. at 256, 519 S.E.2d at 335. 
Initially, we note that the six month 
  time period prescribed in section 1572 did not elapse between June 1996, when 
  the partiesâ€™ separated, and December 1996, when the children began receiving 
  social security payments based on the fatherâ€™s disability status.Â  The evidence 
  is unchallenged that the father was in the process of applying for his social 
  security benefits during that time span and was in fact disabled during that 
  period, although the Social Security Administration had not declared him disabled.Â  
  It is further undisputed that the childrenâ€™s social security benefits total 
  $424 per month, only $60 short of the amount of the fatherâ€™s support obligation 
  under the Child Support Guidelines.Â  Although the mother and stepfather correctly 
  note that the childrenâ€™s social security benefits are not deducted from the 
  fatherâ€™s benefits, we concur with the family court that the benefits are nonetheless 
  available to the children due to the fatherâ€™s disability status and the father 
  is deemed to have made a material contribution to their upkeep.Â  Moreover, we 
  agree with the family courtâ€™s holding that even though the father could be ordered 
  to contribute to child support in excess of the childrenâ€™s social security benefits, 
  the family court has not had occasion to rule on the issue because it was not 
  raised by any of the parties in this case.Â Â  
Under these facts and circumstances, we 
  find no error in the courtâ€™s conclusion that the fatherâ€™s failure to pay support 
  in addition to the childrenâ€™s social security benefits did not amount to a willful 
  failure to support the children.Â  
II.Â  Failure to Visit
The mother and stepfather next assert 
  the family court erred in failing to determine the father willfully failed to 
  visit the children.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-1572(3) provides that parental rights 
  may be terminated if termination is in the best interest of the child and:

The child has lived outside the home of either parent for 
  a period of six months, and during that time the parent has wilfully failed 
  to visit the child.Â  The court may attach little or no weight to incidental 
  visitations, but it must be shown that the parent was not prevented from visiting 
  by the party having custody or by court order.Â  The distance of the childâ€™s 
  placement from the parentâ€™s home must be taken into consideration when determining 
  the ability to visit.

As with failure to support, 
  a parentâ€™s â€œwillfulâ€ failure to visit a child within the meaning of section 
  20-7-1572 is a question of intent to be resolved by the facts and circumstances 
  of each case.Â  Broome, 307 S.C. at 52, 413 S.E.2d at 838; Wilson, 
  344 S.C. at 336, 543 S.E.2d at 582; Parker, 336 S.C. at 256, 519 S.E.2d 
  at 355.Â  Ordinarily, the family court has extensive discretion in making this 
  decision.Â  Yet, the requirement of willfulness must be established by clear 
  and convincing evidence.Â  Broome, 307 S.C. at 52, 413 S.E.2d at 838; 
  Wilson, 344 S.C. at 336, 543 S.E.2d at 582; Parker, 336 S.C. at 
  256, 519 S.E.2d at 335.
In the initial divorce decree, 
  the family court expressly held the issue of visitation in abeyance pending 
  the father obtaining a psychological evaluation from the VA and the guardian 
  providing the court with a recommendation as to visitation.Â  It is uncontested 
  the father obtained the evaluation by the VA in accordance with the order.Â  
  Nonetheless, the guardian ad litem declined to make a recommendation because 
  she desired an independent evaluation.Â  Particularly in light of the fatherâ€™s 
  initial efforts to comply with the guardianâ€™s superfluous requirement that he 
  obtain a psychological evaluation from an â€œindependentâ€ doctor, we cannot conclude 
  the fatherâ€™s failure to ultimately obtain an evaluation from a doctor of the 
  guardianâ€™s choice amounted to either a failure to comply with the terms of the 
  courtâ€™s order or an election to forego his visitation with the children.Â  
We reject the mother and stepfatherâ€™s contention 
  that the fatherâ€™s failure to request a hearing on visitation despite the lack 
  of a recommendation from the guardian constituted an election not to visit the 
  children.Â  Under the express terms of the divorce decree, a request for a hearing 
  was not to be made until after the guardian submitted a proposal as to visitation.Â  
  Significantly, the same family court judge who issued the divorce decree determined 
  in this action that â€œ[s]ince the Guardian made no recommendations, the [father] 
  correctly argues that no request for a hearing was authorized by the Order.â€
The case of Stefan v. Stefan, 320 S.C. 419, 
  465 S.E.2d 734 (Ct. App. 1995) is controlling and edifying in regard to the 
  issue of delegating judicial authority to a guardian to recommend the time for 
  visitation.Â  Stefan states:

The father argues the family court abused its discretion 
  by delegating judicial authority to the parenting specialist and the guardian, 
  and by authorizing the guardian to recommend the time for the resumption of 
  visitation, and modification of visitation.Â  We agree.
In the final analysis it is the family court which is 
  charged with the authority and responsibility for protecting the interest of 
  minors involved in litigation, not the guardian or any other person whom the 
  court may appoint to assist it.Â  While this court can appreciate the frustration 
  of the family court in devising a visitation plan for the husband, it was error 
  to delegate this responsibility to the guardian and the parenting specialist. 
  . . .
. . . In her final order, the trial judge appointed a 
  guardian for the children and directed him to perform certain tasks and to make 
  recommendations prior to the husbandâ€™s visitation being resumed.Â  This was error.

Id. at 422-23, 465 S.E.2d at 736 (footnote 
  omitted) (emphasis added).
We caution family court judges NOT 
  to delegate any responsibility to a guardian in regard to visitation 
  of children with parents.Â  We encourage the Family Court Bench and Bar to strictly 
  adhere to the holding in Stefan.
Because the father was effectively enjoined from 
  visiting the children even after he complied with the terms of the order, we 
  cannot rule that he willfully failed to visit the children during the time the 
  order was in effect.Â  
The mother and stepfather complain that the family 
  court erred in failing to consider the best interests of the children in determining 
  the fatherâ€™s parental rights should not be terminated.Â  We find no reversible 
  error.
Although the family court order does not directly 
  address whether the childrenâ€™s interests would be best served by terminating 
  the fatherâ€™s parental rights, we note that section 20-7-1572 requires both a 
  finding as to the best interests of the child and proof of one or more 
  of the enumerated statutory grounds before termination may be ordered.Â  Inasmuch 
  as the mother and stepfather failed to establish the requisite statutory grounds 
  for termination, any error on the family courtâ€™s part in not expressly ruling 
  on the best interests of the children is of little consequence to the propriety 
  of the courtâ€™s order.
CONCLUSION
We take this opportunity to remind the Bench and 
  Bar that we disapprove of the length of time from the issuance of the Order, 
  dated November 8, 1996, and the response by the guardian and court on October 
  16, 2000.Â  Children should not be held in limbo for an inordinate period of 
  time.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and CURETON, J., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  The fatherâ€™s disabilities include degenerative joint disease, nine 
    knee surgeries, posttraumatic stress disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity 
    disorder, and peripheral nerve damage stemming from his participation in Desert 
    Storm.
