THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Gerrod Lewis,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Â Luke N. Brown, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3600
Heard November 7, 2002 - Filed February 
  18, 2003

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General Christie Newman Barrett; and Solicitor Walter M. 
  Bailey, Jr., for Respondent
      
    
  


CONNOR, J.:Â  Gerrod Lewis was indicted for 
  first degree criminal sexual conduct, two counts of kidnapping, grand larceny 
  of a vehicle, and armed robbery.Â  He appeals the juryâ€™s verdict finding him 
  guilty on all charges. Â Â We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
On June 21, 1999, Jane 
  Doe [1]  and Gill Armstrong were 
  traveling with their infant daughter from Virginia to their home in Florida.Â  
  They stopped at a hotel off I-95 in St. George about 11:00 p.m.Â Â  After checking 
  in, Armstrong went to a nearby restaurant to get some food.Â Â  When he returned, 
  he noticed three men standing in the breezeway near his room.Â  Assuming they 
  were hotel guests, he proceeded back to his room.Â  After putting the food in 
  the room, Armstrong went back outside to the vending machines for drinks.Â  
At the vending machine, 
  a man whom Armstrong later identified as Timothy Washington, placed a gun to 
  his head and demanded money.Â  Lewis and Shermaine Elmore were with Washington.Â  
  Armstrong recognized the three as the same men he had seen in the breezeway 
  minutes earlier.Â  The three assailants demanded that Armstrong take them to 
  his room.Â  
As the men entered the room, 
  Doe was getting out of the shower clad only in a towel.Â  Their daughter was 
  asleep on the bed.Â  The assailants demanded money.Â  When they realized Armstrong 
  and Doe had only fourteen dollars, they became enraged and began searching the 
  room.Â  They did not find anything else in the room.Â  
Lewis and Washington then took turns sexually assaulting 
  Doe in the bedroom while Elmore held Armstrong at gunpoint in the bathroom.Â Â  
  Washington then took Doe into the bathroom and sexually assaulted her in Armstrongâ€™s 
  presence.Â Â  Thereafter, the assailants took Armstrongâ€™s keys and stole his car.Â  
  The car was found a few days later near St. George.Â  
Lewis and Washington were tried 
  together, and both were found guilty of all charges.Â  The trial court sentenced 
  Lewis to five years for grand larceny and thirty years concurrently on each 
  of the remaining charges.Â  
ISSUES

I.Â  Did the trial court err by failing to suppress Armstrongâ€™s 
  in-court identification of Lewis?Â  
II. Did the trial court err in refusing to allow Lewis to 
  strike a juror previously stricken by his co-defendant?Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.
Lewis first argues he is entitled to 
  a new trial because the trial court erred in failing to suppress the in-court 
  identification Armstrong made of him.Â  He contends the trial court erred in 
  not holding a hearing to determine the reliability of the in-court identification 
  and that the identification was unduly suggestive and unreliable.Â  Lewis asserts 
  the error in allowing the in-court identification was not harmless. Â We 
  hold the trial court did not err in failing to hold a hearing and admitting 
  the in-court identification of Lewis.
Armstrong was unable to return to South 
  Carolina from Florida before the trial.Â  Therefore, law enforcement had no opportunity 
  to conduct a lineup prior to trial to determine if Armstrong could identify 
  any of the three assailants.Â  
Before jury selection Lewisâ€™s counsel asked the court to 
  require police or the solicitor to conduct a photo lineup to determine if Armstrong 
  could identify his client or, in the alternative, for the court to suppress 
  any in-court identification of Lewis.Â  The trial court refused.Â  
Subsequently, Lewis requested an in 
  camera hearing prior to Armstrongâ€™s in-court identification.Â  He wanted 
  the court to determine whether the identification was reliable.Â  The trial court 
  denied Lewisâ€™s motion.Â  
An in-court identification of an accused 
  is inadmissible if an out-of-court confrontation such as a showup, lineup, or 
  photo array was so unduly suggestive that it created a very substantial likelihood 
  of irreparable misidentification.Â  State v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 
  552 S.E.2d 300 (2001), cert. denied, ___ U.S. ___ (2002).Â  The United 
  States Supreme Court has crafted a two-pronged inquiry for the trial court to 
  use in determining the admissibility of an out-of-court identification.Â  Neil 
  v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1972).Â  â€˜â€œ[A] court must first determine whether 
  the identification process was unduly suggestive. . . . [It] next must determine 
  whether the out-of-court identification was nevertheless so reliable that no 
  substantial likelihood of misidentification existed.â€™â€Â  State v. Moore, 
  343 S.C. 282, 287, 540 S.E.2d 445, 447 (2000) (quoting Curtis v. Commonwealth, 
  396 S.E.2d 386, 388 (Va. Ct. App. 1990)).
Recently, the South Carolina 
  Supreme Court has set forth the rule trial courts should use in deciding the 
  reliability of in-court identifications.Â  State v. Ramsey, 345 S.C. 607, 
  550 S.E.2d 294 (2001).Â  In Ramsey, the Court stated:

Where identification is concerned, the general rule is that 
  a trial court must hold an in camera hearing when the State offers a 
  witness whose testimony identifies the defendant as the person who committed 
  the crime, and the defendant challenges the in-court identification as being 
  tainted by a previous, illegal identification or confrontation.

Id. at 613, 550 S.E.2d at 297.Â  The Court 
  limited this rule to situations where an in-court identification was the product 
  of an unlawful confrontation or lineup.Â  Id.Â Â  
However, in this case the police did not conduct any 
  kind of pretrial identification which could have contributed to a misidentification 
  of Lewis during trial.Â  Our research reveals no South Carolina case requiring 
  a trial court to conduct an in camera hearing to determine the reliability 
  of an in-court identification, where law enforcement has conducted no pretrial 
  out-of-court identification.Â  Nor has Lewis cited any such case.
â€œGenerally, the decision to 
  admit an eyewitness identification is at the trial judgeâ€™s discretion and will 
  not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of such, or the commission of prejudicial 
  legal error.â€Â  Moore, at 288, 540 S.E.2d at 448.Â  We find no abuse of 
  discretion or prejudicial legal error because the trial court failed to conduct 
  a Neil v. Biggers hearing or to suppress Lewisâ€™s in-court identification.
Ultimately, the reliability 
  and credibility of the in-court identification was a question for the jury, 
  as it was the sole judge of the facts and the credibility of the witnesses.Â  
  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001).Â  Lewisâ€™s counsel 
  subjected Armstrong to extensive cross-examination concerning the accuracy and 
  reliability of his in-court identification.Â  Armstrong explained the extent 
  of his opportunity to view Lewis at the time of the crime, the degree of attention 
  he paid, and the accuracy of his prior description of Lewis. Â In his 
  direct testimony, Armstrong unhesitatingly identified Lewis as one of the assailants, 
  and even though he admitted that a year and a half had elapsed since the crime, 
  he testified he was nevertheless â€œpositiveâ€ about his identification. 
Therefore, the trial court committed 
  no error on this issue.Â  
II.
Lewis additionally argues 
  he is entitled to a new trial because the trial court refused to allow him to 
  strike a juror previously stricken by his co-defendant.
During jury selection Lewis 
  exercised peremptory strikes on nine white jurors.Â  His co-defendant, Washington, 
  also separately struck nine white jurors, including juror 304, a white female.Â  
  At the end of jury selection, the State requested a Batson 
  [2]  hearing.Â  Each defendant separately presented reasons for his respective 
  strikes.Â  Washington explained he struck juror 304 because she was a housewife.Â  
  The trial court found several jurors, including juror 304, had been struck for 
  reasons not race-neutral or gender-neutral. [3] Â  The parties then began selecting a second 
  jury.Â  
Juror 304 was presented again.Â  
  Washington accepted the juror, but Lewis attempted to strike her.Â  At that point, 
  the trial court asked the attorneys to approach the bench and told Lewisâ€™s attorney 
  he could not strike the juror because the court had already held that the reason 
  for the previous strike was pretextual.Â  Lewis therefore accepted the juror.Â  
  After finishing the second jury selection process, Lewis moved to quash the 
  jury and re-select another jury because he was not allowed to exercise a peremptory 
  strike.Â  The following colloquy occurred:

  Mr. Loy [Lewisâ€™s counsel]:Â  Your Honor, my 
  motion is to strike the jury and re-pick based on the following, Your Honor:Â  
  Juror Number 304 was called, when she was called I exercised a strike, struck 
  her, you called us to sidebar, indicated as you had earlier ruled that that 
  was not a race-neutral or gender-neutral strike.
 The Court:Â  
  I did.
  Mr. Loy:Â  That I couldnâ€™t strike her for any reason 
  whatsoever, and in fact was compelled to seat her on the jury.Â  I didnâ€™t want 
  to make the argument there, I attempted to preserve my objection to that instruction 
  by saying pursuant to your instruction at the bench.Â  However, Your Honor, I 
  think if I have independent grounds to strike her separate and apart from what 
  we did last time -- 
  The Court:Â  No, sir.Â  You donâ€™t get to pick and choose.Â  
  When you put on there that thatâ€™s the reason you struck her the first time and 
  I ruled that was not gender or race neutral, that means you cannot strike her.Â  
  Now, put anything you want to on the record.
  Mr. Loy:Â  Thatâ€™s my argument, Your Honor.Â  My argument 
  is that if I have independent reasons for striking her, such as if something 
  -- 
  The Court:Â  I donâ€™t know what the independent reason 
  is.Â  Youâ€™re stuck with what you gave me the first time.Â  I had already ruled 
  you couldnâ€™t put her, but Iâ€™ll let you put anything you want to on the record.
  Mr. Loy:Â  I think, You[r] Honor, itâ€™s akin, although 
  this is not the case, that if I had heard her in the hallway saying they ought 
  to just hang both of those guys and be done with it, that I wouldnâ€™t be compelled 
  to seat her on the jury.Â  Thatâ€™s my argument, I think I should have been allowed 
  to strike her.
  The Court:Â  Iâ€™ll be glad to let you put down whatever 
  independent reason you would have used.
  Mr. Loy:Â  Your Honor, the reason I would have used, 
  the reason I would have struck her was based solely on her demeanor when she 
  came forward on the manner in which she looked at our table versus the Stateâ€™s 
  table entirely independent of what happened during our first jury selection 
  process.
  The Court:Â  All right.Â  Anything else?
  Mr. Loy:Â  No.Â  Thatâ€™s it, Your Honor. 
  The Court:Â  I deny your motion.Â  Anything further?
  Mr. Loy:Â  Not from [sic] on behalf of Mr. Lewis, Your 
  Honor.

Neither the State nor the defendant 
  may exercise peremptory challenges in a racially discriminatory manner.Â  
  State v. Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 499 S.E.2d 209 (1998) (citing Batson 
  v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986), and Georgia v. McCollum, 505 U.S. 
  42 (1992)).Â  The United States Supreme Court let individual states fashion a 
  remedy for striking a juror based upon race.Â  Batson, 476 U.S. at 99 
  n.24.Â  
In State v. Jones, 293 
  S.C. 54, 58, 358 S.E.2d 701, 704 (1987), abrogated on other grounds by 
  State v. Chapman, 317 S.C. 302, 454 S.E.2d 317 (1995), our Supreme Court 
  held that if the trial court finds a Batson violation, â€œthe process of 
  selecting the jury shall start de novo.â€Â  The Court stated, â€œmembers 
  of the tainted jury and all persons who were struck shall be placed back in 
  the jury venire.Â  The jury selection process shall start anew using this â€˜reconstructedâ€™ 
  venire.â€Â  Id. at 58 n.3, 358 S.E.2d at 704 n.3.
Later, in State v. Franklin, 
  318 S.C. 47, 51, 456 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1995), the Court addressed the procedure 
  the trial court should follow when â€œa party attempts to strike from the second 
  venire a person previously ruled stricken in violation of Batson.â€Â  The 
  Court recognized the de novo jury selection procedure established 
  in Jones but held, to protect a venirepersonâ€™s constitutional rights 
  and to prevent rewarding a party for improper conduct, that it was not error 
  for the trial court to disallow a partyâ€™s second attempt to strike a juror who 
  was previously improperly removed from the jury.Â  
However, in this case, Lewis 
  did not strike juror 304 during the first selection process.Â  His co-defendant 
  Washington did.Â  Thus, Lewis argues he should have been able to strike juror 
  304, independent of his co-defendantâ€™s earlier actions.Â  Lewis alleges the trial 
  court erred in imputing the co-defendantâ€™s unconstitutional strike to him, thereby 
  prohibiting Lewis from striking the juror.Â  Moreover, he claims his strike could 
  have been for an intervening, independent reason. 
The State contends Franklin 
  controls these facts because a defendant does not have the right to repeatedly 
  strike a prospective juror on an unconstitutional basis.Â  However, Franklin 
  did not address a situation where co-defendants exercise strikes independent 
  of each other.Â  In Franklin, the issue facing the Court was the â€œclaimed 
  right [of an offending party] to unconstitutionally strike a prospective juror 
  over and over again . . . .â€Â  Id. at 54, 456 S.E.2d at 361.Â  The Court 
  reasoned that allowing the trial court the discretion to seat an improper juror 
  prevented â€œâ€˜giv[ing] the offending party exactly what he wanted, namely,â€™ a 
  jury panel which unconstitutionally excludes a particular juror.â€Â  Id. 
  at 53, 456 S.E.2d at 360 (quoting People v. Moten, 603 N.Y.S.2d 940, 
  947 (N.Y. Sup. Ct. 1993)).Â  
Here, Lewis was not the â€œoffending 
  party.â€Â  Lewis did not strike juror 304 during the first selection process.Â  
  Furthermore, there is no evidence Lewis attempted to strike the juror on an 
  unconstitutional basis during the second selection process.Â  The trial courtâ€™s 
  discretionary remedy for an improper peremptory strike must not infringe on 
  either the jurorâ€™s or the defendantâ€™s constitutional rights.Â  Id. at 
  53, 456 S.E.2d at 360.Â  Lewis is constitutionally entitled to a fair and impartial 
  jury.Â  S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 14; see State v. Harris, 340 S.C. 
  59, 62, 530 S.E.2d 626, 627 (2000) (â€œThe Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments of 
  the United States Constitution guarantee a defendant a fair trial by a panel 
  of impartial and indifferent jurors.â€).Â  Lewisâ€™s entitlement to an impartial 
  jury was not met where the trial court prohibited Lewis from striking a juror 
  he had not previously challenged.
Moreover, Lewis presented an 
  intervening, independent reason to strike the juror.Â  See Franklin, 
  318 S.C. at 54, 456 S.E.2d at 361 (stating a defendant is â€œnot prohibited from 
  bringing to light facts justifying striking the prospective juror which arose 
  after the initial Batson hearingâ€).Â  Lewis stated he attempted to strike 
  the juror because of her demeanor when she came forward.Â  However, the trial 
  court did not even consider Lewisâ€™s explanation for the attempted strike, given 
  the courtâ€™s earlier ruling that Lewis was â€œstuck with what [he] gave [the trial 
  court] the first time.â€Â  This was error.Â  Because Lewis did not strike the juror 
  the first time, he should have been allowed to strike the juror the second time, 
  subject to scrutiny by the court only if the State moved for a Batson 
  hearing.Â  He should also have been allowed to present evidence concerning an 
  intervening reason and had the trial court rule on that.Â  
The State contends the trial 
  court â€œproperly refused to allow Lewis to use subterfuge to discriminate against 
  juror [number 304] for a second time.â€Â  There is no evidence the reason advanced 
  by Lewis to strike the juror was â€œsubterfuge.â€ Â Â Â  
The trial court should have 
  allowed Lewis to exercise a peremptory challenge during the second selection 
  process given Lewis had not already stricken the juror and may have had an intervening 
  reason to later strike the juror.Â  Lewis should not have been held responsible 
  for the unconstitutional strike exercised by his co-defendant.Â  Cf. State 
  v. Carriker, 269 S.C. 553, 238 S.E.2d 678 (1977) (finding the objections 
  of one defendant are not imputable to a co-defendant).
CONCLUSION
The trial courtâ€™s denial 
  of Lewisâ€™s motion to hold an in camera hearing to determine the reliability 
  of an in-court identification is affirmed.Â  However, based on the foregoing 
  analysis concerning the jury selection, we reverse and remand this case for 
  a new trial.Â  
 AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED 
  IN PART, AND REMANDED.
STILWELL, J., concurs and ANDERSON, 
  J., dissents in separate opinion.
ANDERSON, J. (dissenting):Â  I respectfully 
  dissent.Â  The majority concludes the trial court did not err by denying Lewisâ€™s 
  request for an in camera hearing and the trial court should have allowed 
  Lewis to strike a previously stricken juror.Â  I disagree.Â  I VOTE to AFFIRM.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
 On June 21, 1999, Jane Doe 
  [4]  and Gill Armstrong were traveling from Virginia to their home in Florida 
  with their infant daughter.Â  They checked in at the Economy Inn off I-95 in 
  St. George around 11:00 p.m.Â  Leaving Doe and the infant daughter in the hotel 
  room, Armstrong went to the Huddle House to pickup food.Â  When he returned, 
  he noticed three men standing in the breezeway near his room.Â  Assuming they 
  were hotel guests, Armstrong proceeded to his room and was not suspicious of 
  their presence.Â  After putting the food in the hotel room, Armstrong went back 
  outside to the nearby soda machines without completely closing his door.
At the soda machines, a man whom Armstrong 
  identified as Timothy Washington placed a gun to his head.Â  Gerrod Lewis and 
  Shermaine Elmore accompanied Washington.Â  Armstrong recognized the three men 
  as the same men he had seen in the breezeway a few minutes earlier.Â  Washington 
  demanded to go to Armstrongâ€™s hotel room.
As the men entered the hotel room, Doe 
  was getting out of the shower clad only in a towel.Â  The infant daughter was 
  asleep on the bed.Â  The men wanted money.Â  When they realized Armstrong and 
  Doe had only fourteen dollars, they became enraged and searched the room. 
  Â Once they could not find anything of value, Lewis and co-defendant Washington 
  took turns sexually assaulting Doe in the bedroom while co-defendant Elmore 
  held Armstrong at gunpoint in the bathroom.Â  Then Washington took Doe into the 
  bathroom and sexually assaulted her in front of Armstrong.Â  After sexually assaulting 
  Doe, the men took Armstrongâ€™s keys and stole his car.Â  The car was found burned 
  a few days later near St. George.
ISSUES

  
I.Â  Did the trial court err by failing to suppress Armstrongâ€™s 
  identification of Lewis?
II. Did the trial court err in refusing to allow Lewis to 
  strike a previously stricken juror?
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Identification of Lewis
Lewis argues he is entitled to a new trial because 
  the trial court erred in failing to suppress Armstrongâ€™s in-court identification 
  of him.Â  Lewis contends the identification was unduly suggestive and unreliable, 
  and the error was not harmless. Â I disagree.
A.Â  Line-up
Lewis asserts the trial judgeâ€™s failure to suppress 
  the identification was error because the State refused to conduct a non-suggestive 
  lineup before the defendant was brought into the courtroom for trial.Â  I find 
  this argument has no merit.Â  
Before trial, Lewis made a motion to either require a photographic 
  lineup or suppress any identification of him.Â  In connection with the photographic 
  lineup, his counsel stated,

We think as a matter of fundamental fairness [the solicitorâ€™s 
  office] should have done a lineup, either live or in person. . . . They should 
  still be compelled to do a photographic lineup.Â  Itâ€™s not something we have 
  the opportunity to do, obviously as defense, but I do think as a matter of due 
  process and fundamental fairness they should have done that.

In denying the motion for a photographic lineup, 
  the trial judge explained, â€œI canâ€™t require the solicitors or the police officers 
  to do a photo lineup.Â  You know, in many cases thereâ€™s not a photo lineup.Â  
  And I donâ€™t know of any law that would require them to do it, so I have to deny 
  your motion legally.â€Â  
I agree with the trial judge.Â  There is neither 
  a law requiring the solicitor to conduct a photographic lineup, nor a law allowing 
  the judge to order one.Â  Thus, this issue has no merit.
B.Â  InÂ  Camera 
  Hearing
Lewis alleges the trial court erred by denying 
  his request for an in camera hearing to determine the reliability of 
  Armstrongâ€™s identification of him in court.Â  I agree.
The issue posited is novel.Â  Precedentially and 
  by rule language the issue of pre-trial mandatory in camera 
  hearings for identification evidence is extant.Â  Here, we analyze and decide 
  whether an in camera hearing is mandatory in regard to identification 
  evidence that relates solely to an in-court identification.
When Lewisâ€™s motion to compel a lineup was denied, he asked 
  for an in camera hearing prior to the identification being made before 
  the jury.Â  The trial court denied Lewisâ€™s motion:

[Lewisâ€™s counsel]:Â  My re-request at this point is for an 
  in camera hearing prior to them doing that so the Court can make its own determination 
  as to whether or not thatâ€™s a reliable identification.Â  If itâ€™s so unreliable 
  under the circumstances, they shouldnâ€™t allow --
The Court:Â  That means Iâ€™m going to have to try the case 
  twice, which Iâ€™m not going to do.Â  Youâ€™ve got your right to move during the 
  trial at any time to suppress any evidence or identification.Â  Iâ€™m not going 
  to have a hearing beforehand.Â  

â€œThe standard for determining the admissibility of a[n] 
  . . . identification is â€˜whether the identification procedure â€œwas so impermissibly 
  suggestive as to give rise to a very substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification.â€â€™ 
  â€Â  State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 228, 522 S.E.2d 845, 851 (Ct. App. 
  1999) (citing State v. Gambrell, 274 S.C. 587, 590, 266 S.E.2d 78, 80 
  (1980); see also Simmons v. United States, 390 U.S. 377, 88 S.Ct. 
  967, 19 L.Ed.2d 1247 (1968)).Â  â€œA criminal defendant may be deprived of due 
  process of law by an identification procedure that is unnecessarily suggestive 
  and conducive to irreparable mistaken identification.â€Â  State v. Blassingame, 
  338 S.C. 240, 251, 525 S.E.2d 535, 541 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing Stovall v. 
  Denno, 388 U.S. 293, 87 S.Ct. 1967, 18 L.Ed.2d 1199 (1967); Patterson, 
  337 S.C. at 228, 522 S.E.2d at 851-52).
In Patterson, we stated:

Some general guidelines emerge from these [pre-trial identification] 
  cases as to the relationship between suggestiveness and misidentification.Â  
  It is, first of all, apparent that the primary evil to be avoided is â€œa very 
  substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification.â€ . . . While the phrase 
  was coined as a standard for determining whether an in-court identification 
  would be admissible in the wake of a suggestive out-of-court identification, 
  with the deletion of â€œirreparableâ€ it serves equally well as a standard for 
  the admissibility of testimony concerning the out-of-court identification itself.Â  
  It is the likelihood of misidentification which violates a defendantâ€™s right 
  to due process. . . . Suggestive confrontations are disapproved because they 
  increase the likelihood of misidentification, and unnecessarily suggestive ones 
  are condemned for the further reason that the increased chance of misidentification 
  is gratuitous.

337 S.C. at 228-9, 522 S.E.2d at 852 (quoting Neil v. 
  Biggers, 409 U.S. 188, 198 (1972)) (brackets in original).
In State v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 538 S.E.2d 257 
  (Ct. App. 2000), this court articulated the rule:

To determine whether an identification is reliable, it is 
  necessary to consider the factors set forth in Neil v. Biggers: 1) the 
  opportunity of the witness to view the criminal at the time of the crime; 2) 
  the witnessâ€™s degree of attention; 3) the accuracy of the witnessâ€™s prior description 
  of the criminal; 4) the level of certainty demonstrated by the witness at the 
  confrontation; and 5) the amount of time between the crime and the confrontation.Â  
  The corrupting effect of a suggestive identification is to be weighed against 
  these factors.Â  After the trial court determines the witnessâ€™s identification 
  is reliable, the witness is permitted to testify before the jury.Â  

Mansfield, 343 S.C. at 78-79, 538 S.E.2d at 263 (internal 
  citations omitted). 
 In U.S. v. Hill, 967 F.2d 226 (6th 
  Cir. 1992), the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals held the factors in Neil v. 
  Biggers apply to in-court identifications as well as pre-trial identifications.Â  
  The court elucidated:

In this case, the court had to make an ex ante determination 
  of whether to allow a witness, who had never before positively identified the 
  defendant in person, to make an identification in court.Â  We hold that the Biggers 
  analysis applies to such in-court identifications for the same reasons that 
  the analysis applies to impermissibly suggestive pre-trial identifications.Â  
  The due process concerns are identical in both cases and any attempt to draw 
  a line based on the time the allegedly suggestive identification technique takes 
  place seems arbitrary.Â  All of the concerns that underlie the Biggers 
  analysis, including the degree of suggestiveness, the chance of mistake, and 
  the threat of due process are no less applicable when the identification takes 
  place for the first time at trial.

Id. at 232.
â€œ[While] there was no obligation to stage a lineup, . . 
  . there was, however, an obligation to ensure that the in-court procedure here 
  did not simply amount to a show-up.â€Â  U.S. v. Archibald, 734 F.2d 938, 
  941 (2d Cir. 1984).
In the recent case of State v. Cheatham, 349 S.C. 
  101, 561 S.E.2d 618 (Ct. App. 2002), we held:

Where there is an issue as to whether or not an in-court 
  identification by a witness is of independent origin and based upon observations 
  of a suspect other than in the course of any improper confrontation or line-up, 
  the defendant is entitled to an in camera hearing.Â  Thus, our supreme 
  court has â€œadopted a per se rule requiring the court to hold an in 
  camera hearing when the state offers witnesses whose testimony identifies 
  the defendant as the person who committed the crime and the defendant challenges 
  the in-court identification as being tainted by a previous illegal identification.â€ 


Id. at 116, 561 S.E.2d at 626 (citing State v. 
  Williams, 258 S.C. 482, 485, 189 S.E.2d 299, 300 (1972); State v. Simmons, 
  308 S.C. 80, 82-83, 417 S.E.2d 92, 93 (1992); State v. Cash, 257 S.C. 
  249, 185 S.E.2d 525 (1971)); see also State v. Ramsey, 345 S.C. 
  607, 613, 550 S.E.2d 294, 297 (2001) (stating the general rule that a trial 
  court must hold an in camera hearing when the State offers a witness 
  whose testimony identifies the defendant as the person who committed the crime 
  and the defendant challenges the in-court identification).
Further, â€œ[h]earings on the admissibility of confessions 
  or statements by an accused, and pretrial identifications of an accused shall 
  in all cases be conducted out of the hearing of the jury.â€Â  Rule 104(c), SCRE.Â  
  The rule â€œrequires all hearings regarding the admissibility of pretrial identifications 
  (to include any assertion that an in-court identification should be excluded 
  as a result of a pretrial identification) to be heard outside the presence of 
  the jury.â€Â  Cheatham, 349 S.C. at 115-6, 561 S.E.2d at 626 (citing Simmons, 
  308 S.C. 80, 417 S.E.2d 92 (1992)).Â  â€œRule 104(c) unambiguously mandates hearings 
  on the admissibility of out of court identifications of the accused shall in 
  all cases be held outside the presence of the jury.â€Â  Id. at 117, 561 
  S.E.2d at 627.
I respectfully remind the Bench and Bar of the 
  mandate to hold an in camera hearing to determine the reliability of 
  an in-court identification when requested.Â  In Cheatham, we edified: 
  â€œWe reaffirm the per se rule requiring the court to hold an in camera 
  hearing when the state offers witnesses whose testimony identifies the defendant 
  as the person who committed the crime and the defendant challenges the in-court 
  identification as being tainted by a previous illegal identification.â€Â  Id. 
  at 117-18, 561 S.E.2d at 627.
The judge was required to hold an in camera hearing 
  to establish the reliability of the in-court identification.Â  Experimentally 
  and realistically, the conduct of the criminal trial should be imbued with fairness 
  and equanimity to all parties.Â  In a trial setting, I conclude that basic rules 
  of judicial veracity mandate an in camera hearing on the admissibility 
  of the in-court identification of the accused.Â  To allow the fact-finder to 
  hear the in-court identification testimony BEFORE admission into 
  evidence stretches credulity because in the event of INADMISSIBILITY, 
  the jury has already heard the testimony in full.Â  The inquiry then is the efficacy 
  of the judgeâ€™s ruling striking testimony and instructing the jury to disregard 
  the testimony.Â  The rule promulgated by the majority is a prosecutorial halcyonian 
  conquest. 
Thus, the denial of the motion to suppress was error without 
  an in camera hearing.Â  It does not follow, however, that Lewis is entitled 
  to a new trial.Â  I must determine if the error was harmless.Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
C.Â  Harmless Error
â€œ[I]f the identification is corroborated by either 
  circumstantial or direct evidence, then the harmless error rule might be applicable.â€Â  
  State v. Simmons, 308 S.C. 80, 83, 417 S.E.2d 92, 94 (1992) (citing Chapman 
  v. California, 386 U.S. 18, 87 S.Ct. 824, 17 L.Ed.2d 705 (1967)); see 
  also Cheatham, 349 S.C. at 117, 561 S.E.2d at 627 (stating Simmons 
  rule that harmless error rule may be applicable if identification is corroborated 
  by either circumstantial or direct evidence).
In State v. Ramsey, 345 S.C. 607, 550 S.E.2d 
  294 (2001), the defendant did not challenge the testimony of three witnesses 
  who testified they had â€œno doubtâ€ Ramsey was wearing a striped sweater on the 
  day of the murder.Â  Id. at 614, 550 S.E.2d at 298.Â  Given this direct 
  evidence, our supreme court held that failure to conduct an in camera 
  hearing was harmless error.
Similarly in the present case, there was direct 
  evidence that corroborated Armstrongâ€™s identification of Lewis.Â  Even without 
  Armstrongâ€™s testimony, the State presented co-defendant Elmore who testified 
  in detail about Lewisâ€™s involvement in the crime.Â  Elmore said that he, Lewis, 
  and Washington had walked to the Economy Inn from a nearby convenience store.Â  
  He verified the details of the occurrence in the hotel room, including the fact 
  that Lewis sexually assaulted Doe.Â  Thus, even though the trial judge erred 
  in not conducting the in camera hearing, the error was harmless and does 
  not require reversal. 
II.Â  Viability 
  of Previously Stricken Juror
Lewis claims he is entitled to a new trial based 
  on the courtâ€™s refusal to allow him to strike a previously stricken juror.Â  
  I disagree.
 During jury selection, Lewisâ€™s counsel struck 
  nine white jurors.Â  Co-defendant Washingtonâ€™s counsel also struck nine white 
  jurors, including juror number 304, a white female.Â  At the end of the selection, 
  the State requested a Batson [5]  hearing.Â  Lewis and Washingtonâ€™s attorneys 
  separately presented their reasons for each of the strikes.Â  The State argued 
  the explanations were a pretext for purposeful discrimination.Â  The judge found 
  that several jurors, including juror number 304, had been struck for pretextual 
  reasons.

Juror number 304 was called again when the second 
  jury was selected.Â  Washingtonâ€™s attorney accepted the juror, but Lewisâ€™s attorney 
  attempted to strike her.Â  At that point, the trial judge asked the attorneys 
  to approach the bench and told Lewisâ€™s lawyer he could not strike juror number 
  304 for any reason.Â  Lewisâ€™s lawyer then accepted the juror.Â  After the jury 
  was excused, Lewisâ€™s counsel moved to strike the jury and re-pick because he 
  was denied his right to exercise a peremptory strike.Â  The following colloquy 
  occurred:
Mr. Loy [Lewisâ€™s counsel]:Â  Your Honor, my motion is to 
  strike the jury and re-pick based on the following, Your Honor:Â  Juror Number 
  304 was called, when she was called I exercised a strike, struck her, you called 
  us to sidebar, indicated as you had earlier ruled that that was not a race or 
  gender-neutral strike.
The Court: I did.
Mr. Loy: That I couldnâ€™t strike her for any reason whatsoever, 
  and in fact was compelled to seat her on the jury.Â  I didnâ€™t want to make the 
  argument there, I attempted to preserve my objection to that instruction by 
  saying pursuant to your instruction at the bench.Â  However, Your Honor, I think 
  if I have independent grounds to strike her separate and apart from what we 
  did last time â€“
The Court: No, sir.Â  You donâ€™t get to pick and choose.Â  
  When you put on there that thatâ€™s the reason you struck her the first time and 
  I ruled that was not gender or race neutral, that means you cannot strike her.Â  
  Now, put anything you want to on the record. Â  
Mr. Loy: Thatâ€™s my argument, Your Honor.Â  My argument is 
  that if I have independent reasons for striking her, such as if something â€“ 

The Court: I donâ€™t know what the independent reason is.Â  
  Youâ€™re stuck with what you gave me the first time.Â  I had already ruled you 
  couldnâ€™t put her, but Iâ€™ll let you put anything you want to on the record.
Mr. Loy: I think, You[r] Honor, itâ€™s akin, although this 
  is not the case, that if I had heard her in the hallway saying they ought to 
  just hang both of those guys and be done with it, that I wouldnâ€™t be compelled 
  to seat her on the jury.Â  Thatâ€™s my argument, I think I should have been allowed 
  to strike her.
The Court: Iâ€™ll be glad to let you put down whatever independent 
  reason you would have used.
Mr. Loy: Your Honor, the reason I would have used, the reason 
  I would have struck her was based solely on her demeanor when she came forward 
  on the manner in which she looked at our table versus the Stateâ€™s table entirely 
  independent of what happened during our first jury selection process.
The Court: All right.Â  Anything else?
Mr. Loy: No.Â  Thatâ€™s it, Your Honor.
The Court: I deny your motion.Â  Anything further?
Mr. Loy: Not from [sic] on behalf of Mr. Lewis, Your Honor.

In Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79, 80 
  (1986), the United States Supreme Court declared striking a juror solely on 
  the basis of race is unconstitutional.Â  Batson left the remedy for striking 
  a juror based only upon race to each state.Â  Batson, 476 U.S. at 99, 
  n. 24.Â  South Carolina first addressed the remedy for Batson violations 
  in State v. Jones, 293 S.C. 54, 358 S.E.2d 701 (1987) (abrogated on 
  other grounds by State v. Chapman, 317 S.C. 302, 454 S.E.2d 317 (1995)).Â  
  In Jones, our supreme court held that when there is a Batson violation, 
  the jury shall be quashed and â€œthe process of selecting the jury shall start 
  de novo.â€ Jones, 293 S.C. at 58, 358 S.E.2d at 704.Â  The court stated 
  â€œmembers of the tainted jury and all persons who were struck shall be placed 
  back in the jury venire [and] [t]he jury selection process shall start anew 
  using this â€˜reconstructedâ€™ venire.â€Â  Id. at 58, n. 3, 358 S.E.2d at 704, 
  n. 3. 
In State v. Franklin, 318 S.C. 47, 456 
  S.E.2d 357 (1995), our supreme court addressed the procedure when a party attempts 
  to strike from the second venire a person previously stricken in violation of 
  Batson.Â  The court noted â€œ[t]he majority of jurisdictions addressing 
  the question of whether the trial judge may seat a juror improperly excluded 
  in violation of Batson have found no error in seating such a juror.Â  
  The rationale for allowing the trial judge the discretion to seat the improper 
  juror is sound.â€Â  Franklin, 318 S.C. at 52, 456 S.E.2d at 360.Â  The court 
  quoted People v. Moten, 603 N.Y.S.2d 940 (1993) as follows:

To hold otherwise would inadvisably reward a party for his 
  own improper conduct, as would the declaration of a mistrial, which, in my view 
  is an inappropriate remedy where the court is confronted with a valid Batson 
  . . . challenge.Â  The declaration of a mistrial, as an alternative to a difficult 
  decision involving a remedy for a Batson . . . violation, merely avoids 
  the critical issue and is inappropriate since such a declaration would give 
  the offending party exactly what he wanted, namely, a different jury panel.Â  
  Thus, it would reward him for the very discrimination which Batson . 
  . . [was] designed to prevent.Â  

Franklin, 318 S.C. at 52, 456 S.E.2d at 360 (quoting 
  Moten, 603 N.Y.S.2d at 947) (brackets in original).
The court further noted that â€œthe defendantâ€™s 
  constitutional right to a fair and impartial jury is [not] in any way violated 
  by this procedure.â€Â  Id. at 53, 456 S.E.2d at 360.Â  The court held that 
  â€œonce a new venire has been selected . . . it is within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion 
  to fashion the appropriate remedy under the particular facts of each case and, 
  as long as neither partyâ€™s constitutional rights are infringed, that remedy 
  may include the seating of an improperly challenged juror.â€Â  Id. at 53, 
  456 S.E.2d at 360 (citing Jefferson v. State, 595 So.2d 38, 41 (Fla. 
  1992)).
 In the present case, the jury selection process 
  began anew after the first jury was set aside.Â  Lewis does not challenge the 
  trial judgeâ€™s ruling that juror number 304 was first stricken in violation of 
  Batson.Â  Instead, he professes he had an independent reason for striking 
  the juror during the second jury selection, namely â€œher demeanor when she came 
  forward on the manner in which she looked at our table versus the Stateâ€™s table 
  entirely independent of what happened during our first jury selection process.â€
The trial judge should have allowed Lewis to state on the 
  record his reason(s) for wanting to strike the juror during the second jury 
  selection and not after the jury selection was completed.Â  However, there was 
  no error in seating the juror.Â  Lewis was not denied his peremptory challenge.Â  
  Instead, he was prohibited from exercising it in a racially discriminatory manner.Â  
  The trial judge properly refused to allow Lewis to discriminate against juror 
  number 304 during the second jury selection.Â  Further, I find no evidence that 
  Lewis suffered any prejudice from having juror number 304 on the jury.

 
   
    [1] Â  To protect the female victimâ€™s identity, she has been referred to 
    as Jane Doe.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).

 
   
    [3] Â Â  Lewis does not appeal the trial courtâ€™s decision to quash the first 
    jury after finding the parties exercised strikes in a discriminatory fashion. 
  

 
   
    [4] Â Â  To protect the female victimâ€™s identity, she has been referred 
    to as Jane Doe.

 
   [5] Â Â  Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Charles Butler,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Saluda County
J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3601
Heard December 11, 2002 â€“ Filed February 
  24, 2003

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellant Defender Robert M. Dudek and Assistant 
  Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, both of Columbia; for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles 
  H. Richardson and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman M. Rapoport, all 
  of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Charles Butler was indicted for trafficking 
  in cocaine and unlawful possession of a pistol.Â  A jury convicted him of both 
  charges and the trial court sentenced him to ten years imprisonment for trafficking 
  in cocaine and three years imprisonment for unlawful possession of a pistol.Â  
  Butler appeals arguing the trial court erred in denying his motion to suppress 
  the evidence obtained as a result of an unlawful search.Â  We reverse and remand.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Officer Todd Cook testified that on the evening 
  of February 23, 2000, he stopped a van because the vehicle had no taillights.Â  
  The driver exited the van and he and Officer Cook walked to the rear of the 
  vehicle.Â  Cook stated that, as he was writing out a warning ticket to the driver 
  for defective rear lights, he could smell an odor of alcohol coming from the 
  driver.Â  He asked the driver whether there was anything inside the van he needed 
  to know about, such as â€œillegal contrabandâ€ (sic)Â  or any alcohol.Â  Cook stated 
  that he had a suspicion that there was some alcohol in the van because he could 
  smell it on the driver and stated, â€œfor my safety and his safety I just wanted 
  to check, make sure nothing illegalâ€”anything else was going on with the traffic 
  stop.â€Â  Additionally, Officer Cook testified â€œwhen he [the driver] was walking 
  towards me from the van, I smelled alcohol.â€Â  He could not tell if the alcohol 
  was coming from the driver or inside the van, but he suspected there was alcohol 
  in the van.Â  Cook proceeded to the passenger side of the van to get â€œthe passenger 
  out.â€Â  Butler was the passenger he removed from the van.Â  Officer Cook also 
  indicated there were additional passengers in the back seat of the van.
Butler objected to admissibility of the evidence Officer Cook obtained 
  as a result of the stop and subsequent search of Butler.Â  The trial court excused 
  the jury and conducted an in camera hearing.
During the in camera hearing, Officer Cook testified as follows during 
  direct examination:

Q:     Trooper, why did you get the individuals that were inside 
  the van out?
A:      For my protection and their protection.
Q:      What were you going to do when you got them out?
A:      Do a routine pat down.
Q:      A pat down?
A:      Yes.
Q:      Terry frisk, okay.Â  Did you check the passenger?Â  
  Did you attempt to check the passenger for weapons or a weapon?
A:      Yes sir, I did.
Q:      What happened after you attempted to check for weapons?
A:      The passenger, Mr. Butler fled on foot.
Q:Â      What was the result of your check of him or your pat 
  down of him?
A:      Just his outer clothes.

  
    *  
    *  
    *  
  

Q:      What did you do and what did you find?Â  Did you feel 
  anything?
A:      Yes, sir.Â  During my pat down I patted down the pocket 
  and outside the pocket, and I felt what felt like to be a pistol.Â  And at that 
  time, he took off running.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

  
    *  
    *  
    *  
  

Q:      [Y]ou got the individuals out for a pat down because 
  there were other ones there?
A:      Yeah.
Q:      Okay.
A:Â Â Â Â Â  I had suspicion that there was alcohol in the van 
  from the traffic stop.

During cross-examination of Officer Cook, he testified 
  as follows:

Q:Â Â Â Â Â  [W]as [Butler] doing anything wrong, that you could 
  see, in the van . . . when he was sitting there?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  Well, I was in the process of investigating.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  But was he doing anything wrong to cause you to investigate him, sit 
  down in the front seat?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  I mean - -
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  What was he doing but sitting there?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  Well, you know, I smelled alcohol.Â  I thought it was coming from inside 
  the van, and thatâ€™s what - - if thatâ€™s what youâ€™re asking me.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  What was this man doing?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  I was investigating further.

When asked on re-direct why he removed Butler 
  from the van, Officer Cook indicated that the driver had given him an incorrect
